prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to detect the 183.3 GHz water line redshifted to a sky frequency of 110.5 GHz (for a z = 0.66).
To estimate sensitivity, we base our values on the previous detection of water maser emission in this source (Barvainis & Antonucci 2005). The peak line flux density is ~5 mJy, with a total width of 40 km/s. For a 1.875 GHz spw in FDM mode, we will comfortably cover this line, even if the line width if broader than 40 km/s. With a channel width of 3 km/s we will also achieve enough spectral resolution to sample narrow line widths.
For a 5 sigma detection, we request an RMS sensitivity of 1 mJy/beam in a 6 km/s channel, achievable with 50 minutes on source and 1 SB. We thus request a total of 2.2 hours for this science goal, which includes overheads.
Water lines are known to have very high velocity components (e.g. Braatz et al. 2004), which we would like to detect. For this reason, we place two overlapping spws, in two basebands, to cover a total of ~ 9500 km/s.
We also add two continuum SPWs in order to measure sensitively the continuum and form an SED using 3 bands.

The lines might be as narrow as 3 kms, so we need the higher spectral resolution. Since we expect the line to be broader we will average over 6 km/s for the sensitivity calculation, and can average further in case of a broader line to improve our SNR.
Water lines are known to have very high velocity components (e.g. Braatz et al. 2004), which we would like to detect. For this reason, we place two overlapping spws, in two basebands, to cover a total of ~ 4500 km/s (and to account for any uncertainty in z). We also add two continuum SPWs to measure the SED.

We select the same configuration (C36-4) for the science goals. At band 3 it corresponds to 0.7 arcsecs. The reason to use this configuration in band 7 is to resolve the starburst contribution. At band 3, a more extended configuration will help with the shadowing. We may be able to resolve the maser emission as well, if not arising from the AGN but further out in the galaxy.

We aim to detect the 380.2 GHz water line redshifted to a sky frequency of 229.0 GHz (for a z = 0.66).
To estimate sensitivity, we base our values on the previous detection of water maser emission in this source (Barvainis & Antonucci 2005). The peak line flux density is ~5 mJy, with a total width of 40 km/s. For a 1.875 GHz spw in FDM mode, we will comfortably cover this line, even if the line width if broader than 40 km/s. With a channel width of 1.5 km/s we will also achieve enough spectral resolution to sample narrower line widths. Given the possibility, we would like to keep the finest spectral resolution to be sensitive to extremely narrow lines if present, we will smooth offline to achieve our sensitivity goal.
For a 5 sigma detection, we request an RMS sensitivity of 1 mJy/beam in a 4 km/s channel (we will smooth offline), achievable with 43 minutes on source. We thus request a total of 1.26 hours for this science goal, which includes overheads.

For a 1.875 GHz spw in FDM mode, we will comfortably cover this line, even if the line width if broader than 40 km/s. With a channel width of 1.5 km/s we will also achieve enough spectral resolution to sample narrower line widths. Given the possibility, we would like to keep the finest spectral resolution to be sensitive to extremely narrow lines if present, we will smooth offline to achieve our sensitivity goal.
Water lines are known to have very high velocity components (e.g. Braatz et al. 2004), which we would like to detect (and to account for any uncertainty in z). For this reason, we place two overlapping spws, in two basebands, to cover a total of ~ 4500 km/s. We also add two continuum SPWs to measure the SED.

We select the same configuration (C36-4) for the science goals. At band 6 it corresponds to 0.3 arcsecs. The reason to use this configuration in band 7 is to resolve the starburst contribution. At band 6, a more extended configuration will help with the shadowing. We may be able to resolve the maser emission as well, if not arising from the AGN but connected to the starburst emission.
We select continuum-only TDM SPWs for a sentitive detection of the continuum emission.

We select an angular resolution of 0.2 to to image the cool dust component, and determine if there is a starburst contribution. We select Band 7 since there is less contamination from the AGN.
At z=0.66, 1 arcsec is 7.0 kpc, and we expect the dust source might be on scales from 500 pc to 5 kpc. The ALMA-detected sources from the same sample are compact in an 1 arcsec beam (C. Lonsdale, priv. comm.), which tells us they are smaller than 8-10 kpc. If emission is from a torus it will be unresolved in a 0.2 arcsec beam (1.4 kpc), otherwise it can come from the starburst.

We estimate the expected continuum flux from a comparison with a similar source to J0804, J0652, which is very similar and has been observed by ALMA Cycle 0 (Lonsdale et al. 2015 ApJ submitted.)
J0652 is a factor of 3 less luminous than 0804 in the MIR, therefore we estimate from our SED model fit to 0652 that J0804 we might be expected to have estimate log LFIR = 12.2. This means we can rule out star formation > 100 M suns/yr ( log LFIR>12.0) if we can detect 0804+16 at 1.7 mJy.
Therefore our aim if 1.7 mJy continuum, which we can with a SNR of 20 in approximately 11 minutes, therefore requesting 33 minutes for this science goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the fundamental lines of water at 183 GHz and 380 GHz in a type 2 quasar at z = 0.66. Extremely luminous water maser emission at 22 GHz has been previously detected in this intermediate redshift target, pointing to large reservoirs of water around its active nucleus. Detection of these sub-millimeter lines would provide a new tracer of energetic phenomena and would help constrain the physical paramters and excitation conditions in an active environment. All previous attempts to observe water at 183 GHz and 380 GHz from ground-base telescopes have been extremely challenging due to the high water opacity at those frequencies in our atmosphere. The best place to currently search for them is in high redshift galaxies. Only with ALMA can these lines be observed with enough sensitivity. Moreover, before Band 5 becomes available, this is the only source with a powerful megamaser detection that can currently be observed. The target is also part of a radio-loud, extremely luminous MIR sample; if detected in the sub-millimeter, this sample might become an excellent place to search for new megamasers, making this an important pilot.
